ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
We learned a general understanding of most aspects of Yiddish grammar and productive fundamentals of vocabulary, along with some more nuanced aspects of the language which relate to translation. We also learned how to use resources like Verterbukh to look up forms we dont know.  

By the end you can pretty reliable translate an unseen document well with the aid of a dictionary

I learned to translate yiddish text ranging from Eastern European 18th century text to modern US Hasidic writings. I also learned a lot about Yiddish culture and Jewish history that I hadnt learned in any other class at Yale.
Basic grammar of Yiddish with a ton of interesting translation work.
I learned about Yiddish grammar and texts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: excellent material, amazing outcomes
Weaknesses: perhaps it would be nice to focus slightly more on speaking? Idk, its hard to tell

This class is fantastic! It (and Josh) is a real gem. By the middle of the semester youre pretty much able to translate anything with the help of a dictionary. We explored a really wide range of Yiddish text/writers. It does move really really fast though, which can be difficult to manage at times.
No weaknessesthe class was always a joy and we learned so much in a short period of time. I would recommend it to anyone remotely interested in Yiddish.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. It wont really teach you to speak Yiddish, but you will get the opportunity to see an accelerated treatment of the language which lets you do really amazing stuff by the end.

Take this class! Take it earlyif youre at all interested in doing research/taking other Jewish studies classes, its invaluable to be able to read (or at least get the gist of) Yiddish primary sources. Its also just such a wonderful learning environment. Its never about the grade or an assignment, its about learning the material and if you make a mistake, you fix it without worry about being penalized. Josh lets you ask questions and explore topics that interest you and really it feels like learning for the sake of learning and improving your skill level.
Yes, 100%. Take it if youd like to dabble in Yiddish. If youre sure you want to learn to speak the language, take L1-L2, but this class will get you translating with a dictionary quickly.

I would definitely recommend this course! It was a great way to learn a bit of Yiddish while also getting to read important Yiddish texts. Josh Price is a very kind and helpful teacher. He clearly cares a lot about the Yiddish language and is very knowledgeable about the langauge.
